rules.natural: Either the EPA Regulation requires an environmental impact assessment, or the EPA Regulation requires a habitat preservation plan.

In the event that the EPA Regulation applies to the development project, then if it is not the case that the environmental agency discovering an endangered species leads to the modification of construction plans when the site contains that species, the development project is not halted.
One of the following is true: the EPA Regulation applies to the development project, or state law supersedes the EPA Regulation.

rules.prover9_expression: (challenged(developer, EPA_Regulation) -> (supersedes(state_law, EPA_Regulation) -> (-(discovered(environmental_agency, endangered_species) -> (contains(development_site, endangered_species) -> modifies(development_project, construction_plans))) -> -halted(development_project))))
rules.natural: Whenever the developer challenges the EPA Regulation, then given that state law supersedes the EPA Regulation, the project is not halted unless the agency's discovery leads to plan modification for a site containing an endangered species.
Either the developer challenges the EPA Regulation, or the court upholds the EPA Regulation.

rules.prover9_expression: (exempted(development_project, EPA_Regulation) | (upheld(court, EPA_Regulation) -> (supersedes(state_law, EPA_Regulation) -> (-(discovered(environmental_agency, endangered_species) -> (contains(development_site, endangered_species) -> modifies(development_project, construction_plans))) -> -halted(development_project)))))
rules.natural: The development project is exempted from the EPA Regulation, or else, if the court upholds the EPA Regulation, then provided state law supersedes it, the project is not halted unless the agency's discovery leads to plan modification for a site with an endangered species.
On the condition that the EPA Regulation requires a habitat preservation plan, the development project is permitted.
If the EPA Regulation is enforced on the development project, then the development project violated the EPA Regulation.
Whenever the development site qualifies as a protected wetland, the development project is permitted.
The development site qualifies as a protected wetland, or the development site contains an endangered species.
Under the condition that the development project modifies its construction plans, the development project is permitted.
If the environmental consultant identifies an endangered species, then should the development site contain that endangered species, the development project modifies its construction plans.
Either the environmental consultant identifies an endangered species, or the environmental agency discovers an endangered species.
If it is not the case that the EPA Regulation requiring an environmental impact assessment leads to the project being permitted, then the development project is approved.
Should it not be true that the environmental agency discovering an endangered species leads to plan modification when the site contains that species, then the development project is halted.

Provided that the lack of permission due to the EPA Regulation's environmental impact assessment requirement does not entail the project is unapproved, then the EPA Regulation is enforced on the development project.

Whenever the absence of permission from the EPA Regulation's environmental impact assessment requirement failing to imply the project is unapproved holds, then the development project did not violate the EPA Regulation.

facts.natural: It is not the case that the development project is exempted from the EPA Regulation.

steps.natural: If it is not the case that the failure of the EPA Regulation's environmental impact assessment requirement to permit the project implies the project is not approved, then the development project violated the EPA Regulation.

Under the condition that the EPA Regulation requires an environmental impact assessment, the development project is permitted.

If the court upholds the EPA Regulation, then assuming state law supersedes it, the project is not halted provided the agency's discovery does not compel plan modification for an endangered species-containing site.

Provided that state law supersedes the EPA Regulation, then if the discovery of an endangered species by the agency does not result in plan modification when the site contains that species, the project is not halted.
In the event that the environmental agency's discovery of an endangered species does not cause plan modification for a site containing that species, then the development project is not halted.
Should the environmental agency discover an endangered species, then whenever the development site contains that endangered species, the development project will modify its construction plans.
In the event that the development site contains an endangered species, the development project modifies its construction plans.
Should the development site contain an endangered species, then the development project is permitted.
